Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Thinking of improving the auto generation of test cases
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12311356; y=5MbF6ceoMO9flmWxk3qsE3YUJfuNaDg2JN-XVOGf9xpI2-g
X-Yahoo-Profile: saldin_s

Hi Kevin,

I have just gone through the demo and it is impressive
with the parameters of primitive data types such as
int, String, etc. How about generating the unit tests
for Objects such as class instances ?

For instance, if my method is:

public Student getFirstStudent(School school)
{
}

How do we generate the test data for the classes
Student and School ? Is there any such kind of demos
that I can refer to ?

Thanks and Regards,
Saldin

--- Kevin Lawrence <kev.lawrence@...> wrote:

> On 12/27/06, junitheadache
> <bohs01@...> wrote:
> > hmm, to be honest, I haven't had much experience
> with TDD or JUnit
> > till I started on my honors project  about a
> couple of months ago.
> > I've done much research however and have written a
> small lab
> > excercise using TDD.
> >
> > As for what makes me think its a good idea, well
> basically all the
> > articles I read and the people I've spoken to
> remark on two reasons
> > why people do not pick up TDD, firstly being the
> test-first concept
> > of it is difficult to grasp and secondly that they
> do not see the
> > benefits in using it.
> >
> 
> As several other people have stated, TDD is not
> (primarily) about
> testing. It is about design.
> 
> There is value, though, in generating JUnit tests
> both for people who
> are not able or not willing to do TDD. We (Agitar)
> have been working
> on this problem and have an experimental version of
> our test
> generation engine available at www.junitfactory.com.
> There is a free
> demo online and I can get an invitation for anyone
> who would like to
> try it for real in Eclipse.
> 
> It is primarily designed for people who do not do
> TDD but we,
> internally, find it a useful complement to cover the
> cases that TDD
> misses or to bring legacy code under test in the way
> that Michael
> Feathers describes in Working Effectively with
> Legacy Code.
> 
> 
> Kevin
> 
> www.junitfactory.com
> You send us code. We send you tests.
>
